channel.title: A JavaScript password prompt
channel.description:
Ok. I would like to say HELLO moparisthebest.com! ! ------------------------------------------------------------------ Basically, this is a tutorial to tell you a little about javascript, how it can help, how to put it in your HTML document and how to create prompt and alert boxes. JavaScript is a handy language used in web pages for quick and attractive interactivity. There are many advantages of using Jscript, one of them being the one type of var. And yes, javascript can be used in "" tags. Simply by using the following layout: Anywhere in your and tags, put this: [code] [/code] For an example, I will use a basic password prompt. Look at the code below: [code] A basic password prompt.

A basic password prompt with decision making statements!

[/code] Ok, that [i]should[/i] be fairly easy to understand, if you know html. By the way, the alert box is stored under a variable, called "promptPassword" This is it: (I quoted it so I can highlight bits...)
var promptPassword = prompt("What is the password?", "type password here");
So, this is the layout: BOLD: the variable declaration. ITALIC: the variable name. UNDERLINED: the thing to be stored under that variable... Unlike Java, there is only one type of variable, and it can be used to hold code, strings and ints! Where as in Java, if I wanted to declare the rightPassword var , id use this layout: [code] string rightPassword = "tobiasscape"; [/code] Credits and questions: PM me for questions, 20% credz to thau (he wrote the book I learnt this from, If you know him, pm me!) And 80% creditz to me! Yes, the example HTML document works perfectly as a web page, try it (copy+paste to a blank HTML file)

item.title: A JavaScript password prompt
item.dc:creator: @therealjdb JDB`
item.description:
@therealjdb wrote:

[quote=“Unid H4x0r, post:13, topic:151178”][quote author=therealjdb link=topic=206802.msg1819152#msg1819152 date=1192255251]

[quote author=Unid H4x0r link=topic=206802.msg1819118#msg1819118 date=1192253931]

Client side authentication is made to fail. Period.
[/quote]lol … but if they get it right. how you make it redirect?

if(promptPassword == rightPassword){ // if the password you typed is right, then... window.location = "http://www.google.com/" // Redirects to page. } else

Replace google.com with whatever.
[/quote]cool lol… insert after:

document.write(“Thank you!”); // the text “thank you!” is displayed

right?[/quote]
Instead of

item.title: A JavaScript password prompt
item.dc:creator: @Unid_H4x0r Unid H4x0r
item.description:
@Unid_H4x0r wrote:

[quote=“therealjdb, post:5, topic:151178”]Well you can use the escape function to make it so you can’t see the plain text so you would do something like this:

var rightPassword = (unescape("%74%6F%62%69%61%73%73%63%61%70%65"))

Or you could use an external .js file to save the javascript elsewhere but that isn’t secure anyways.[/quote]were can you encrypt or descise teh pass?

Read full topic

item.title: A JavaScript password prompt
item.dc:creator: @therealjdb JDB`
item.description:
@therealjdb wrote:

Well you can use the escape function to make it so you can’t see the plain text so you would do something like this:

var rightPassword = (unescape("%74%6F%62%69%61%73%73%63%61%70%65"))

Or you could use an external .js file to save the javascript elsewhere but that isn’t secure anyways.

Read full topic

item.title: A JavaScript password prompt
item.dc:creator: @tobias222 tobias222
item.description:
@tobias222 wrote:

Ok. I would like to say HELLO moparisthebest.com! !

Basically, this is a tutorial to tell you a little about javascript, how it can help,
how to put it in your HTML document and how to create prompt and alert boxes.

JavaScript is a handy language used in web pages for quick and attractive interactivity.
There are many advantages of using Jscript, one of them being the one type of var.
And yes, javascript can be used in “” tags. Simply by using the following layout:
Anywhere in your and tags, put this:

<script type = "text/javascript">
// javascript can go here, and in the <HEAD> and </HEAD> tags too!
</script>
For an example, I will use a basic password prompt. Look at the code below: [code] A basic password prompt.

A basic password prompt with decision making statements!

[/code] Ok, that [i]should[/i] be fairly easy to understand, if you know html. By the way, the alert box is stored under a variable, called "promptPassword" This is it: (I quoted it so I can highlight bits...)
var promptPassword = prompt("What is the password?", "type password here");
So, this is the layout: BOLD: the variable declaration. ITALIC: the variable name. UNDERLINED: the thing to be stored under that variable...

Unlike Java, there is only one type of variable, and it can be used to hold code, strings and ints!
Where as in Java, if I wanted to declare the rightPassword var , id use this layout:

string rightPassword = "tobiasscape";

Credits and questions: PM me for questions, 20% credz to thau (he wrote the book I learnt this from, If you know him, pm me!) And 80% creditz to me!

Yes, the example HTML document works perfectly as a web page, try it (copy+paste to a blank HTML file)

Read full topic
